citeinfo.origin: Clifford A. Barnes and Thomas G. Thompson of the University of Washington
citeinfo.title: Physical and Chemical Investigations in Bering Sea and Portions of the North Pacific Ocean

abstract.p: The Bering Sea has been one of the least investigated of the larger bodies of salt water. Opportunity for the study of the physical and chemical conditions of its water was afforded in 1933 and again in 1934. During these years, investigations were undertaken with the following objectives: (1) To make temperature and chlorinity measurements from which density distribution and resulting currents could be computed, (2) to augment, where it was possible the computed currents with direct currents measurements, and (3) to ascertain the distribution of dissolved oxygen and nutrients salts in that region.

[Reference: Barnes, C.A. and T.G. Thompson. 1938. Physical and Chemical Investigations in Bering Sea and Portions of the North Pacific Ocean. University of Washington Publications in Oceanography. Vol. 3, No. 2, pp. 35-79, and Appendix, pp. 1-164.]
This volume may be found at many university libraries.

descript.purpose: To report findings of the physical and chemical investigations in Bering Sea and portions of the North Pacific Ocean.
